+Steafán Fox "I'm glad you used the photon and relativity, it is a 
brilliant way to describe the metaphor of (how I would imagine) the one 
witness' reality and time; as if space-time is a wave washing over the 
one." I created it on the spot lol its one of those rare analogies you come 
up with that make philosophers drool. I have made few analogies that fit so 
perfectly for a claim so difficult to support.

"can you not imagine that science is rediscovering and renaming these 
phenomenon that ancient Israelites labelled as gods and elohim (think of 
the fundamental forces)" When Theists do not understand a particular 
phenomenon they say God did it, when Atheists do not understand it they say 
it is fundamental. This does not mean God does not exist just as it does 
not mean there is nothing fundamental. It is also the composition fallacy 
to think that since there are things that were first thought to be miracles 
that are now known not to be, that therefore all things are not miracles. I 
do not think the discovery of laws rules out God, rather that it suggests 
ingenious order. When I was fourteen I asked myself "Why did God create the 
universe over seven days? Surely he could have done it instantaneously" At 
that time I played a game called minecraft where you can go mining and then 
using that stone to build stuff. On it, I built a castle that required 
50,000 stone and took two weeks to build (I spent all day on it) and once I 
had finished it was very rewarding. A few months later they released 
creative mode, a mode that gave you an infinite amount of stone and other 
resources. However when I created buildings on it, It was not rewarding as 
it became too easy and I chose to use the other mode instead. From this I 
realized that this was why God didn't create the universe instantaneously, 
he chose to do it the long way, following the laws he had created. For 
example when he created Adam and Eve he did not create them from nothing, 
he used dust, converting every atom to carbon and rearranging the atoms to 
create every complex structure of the body. He decided to create these 
things in an orderly fashion. Then when I was seventeen I thought back to 
that idea and asked "If God chose to create the universe in an orderly way, 
did he also choose to create the laws in a orderly way?" From this I 
postulated that the laws are based on intuitive principles that are most 
likely simple. When learning about the four fundamental forces I assumed 
they were different manifests of the same thing before I even heard of 
unified field theory. I think almost all laws are related and the 
relationships between them will be so ingenious that it will be what 
mathematicians think of whilst masturbating. I also think this ingenious 
order will be true with the designs of organisms. From an evolutionary 
perspective we would expect life to be simpler than first thought, from a 
creation perspective we would expect life to be more complex than first 
thought, so complex that you would think such design would require the 
engineering of - quite literally - a god. This one theological argument is 
the butterfly effect of my life, my interest in philosophy has now extended 
to theoretical physics. I now spend an abnormal amount of hours each day 
thinking of hypotheses (Admittedly, this also includes morality and 
theology) and aim to become a Theoretical Physicist.

"Look at all ancient cultures, they had a similar narrative" From a 
biblical world view these cultures have these gods because the original 
story got mythologized after the tower of babel (that is, after the 
confusion of languages and God's command for people to migrate the earth 
which I will talk about when I create the next message) a bit like a game 
of telephone. However, there is also a possibility that its origin is from 
people deciding to worship other gods. We cannot know so its pure

"Yet these archetypical stories are so universal that one can't possibly, 
logically say that any scripture has the authentic "written from the hand"

As mentioned before there are legends of a global flood all over the world.

even if Christianity was based on visions I could still believe it to be

comments.text:
+Steafán Fox Instead of presenting the case myself, I will link you to a 
page that addresses many areas and if you have specific questions I will 
answer them myself.

creation(dot)com/qa#Geology

"How did the universe come into being, from the start right up to this 
moment?" This would take forever to do in one message so I will address a 
single part of the timeline in a series of messages. In this one I will 
start from the very beginning - or more accurately before that (Even before 
isn't exactly accurate)

Before 'the all': 

 In this message I will explain the nature of God as that was all that was 
there before the all. This is of course metaphysics, so the explanation is 
purely philosophical. The bible begins with "In the beginning God created 
the heavens and the earth" The reason it says beginning is because this is 
the beginning of time. As incomprehensible as this is, God is timeless, 
having no past nor future. There was no before the universe. For God there 
is just the present. Think of God like a photon. Relative to us, the photon 
hits our retina, relative to the photon that just hit the retina, all 
things have happened, even if time is infinite. In a way all things remain 
present to the photon too, as the time it hit the retina happened just as 
long ago as any other point in time. Why? because there is no time to the 
photon. As a ten year old kid I remember trying to imagine what it was like 
before everything. I imagined God as a spiritual human floating in space, 
having a language for no reason, a body for no reason and floating in space 
for no reason. This is not the case, God only chose to take the form of a 
human in heaven. He is not restricted by that form. This reminds me of the 
trinity and how many people have a problem with how God could be multiple 
entities at once. I would explain it myself but this video does it 
elegantly, using logic (not the layman 'logic') making the argument almost 
irrefutable.

www(dot)youtube(dot)com/watch?v=bUy-H5MmeGU

God has created absolutely everything, matter, space, time and possibly 
even mathematics (there is disagreement about the latter, mathematics could 
be absolute or we  maybe unable to comprehend how mathematics may not be 
true for all things since we live in a universe that is ruled by 
mathematics). 

A common question asked about God is why does he exist? We do not know. 
However this question could be broken down further to why does anything 
exist? This is the golden question of metaphysics and there are two 
responses to this. The first is 'why does there have to be a reason?' and 
the second is that the answer is probably beyond our comprehension. When we 
ask questions they usually lead to more questions, this suggests we know 
nothing. If we struggle to understand the nature of our own universe, how 
can we expect to understand what is beyond it?

comments.text:
+Steafán Fox "A hypothesis is not accepted as true until proven so. (think 
guilty until proven innocent)" That doesn't stop people from believing it 
to be true. Why else do you think Physicists talk so dogmatically about the 
multiverse? There is a common saying that it is either God or a multiverse. 
The conclusion is made through reason, not observation.

"The multiverse hypothesis is generally based off the ideas of M-brane 
theory" M-brane theory has no tangible evidence to support it. It does not 
deserve to be called a theory. It is like many worlds 'theory'.

"Creationism is a hypothesis, based usually on several ideas
-the inherent order in the universe is the result of intelligent design
-nothing has effect without cause
-humans are too rare to be the result of a random process of evolution" 
There are far more 'ideas' to it than that and the ones you listed aren't 
accurate. I will address each point respectively:

-Fine tuned laws suggest design (I know of two counter arguments to this 
and I have counter arguments to those counter arguments)

-Everything that begins to exist has a cause

-Certain systems of organisms cannot be any simpler aka irreducible 
complexity 

Now those are philosophical ideas we have there is also evidence against 
evolution such as genetic entropy, finding blood vessels, bone matrix and 
elastic tissue in dinosaurs, lack of transitional fossils (with just a 
handful of disputable once), the ridiculous amount of modern birds in 
dinosaur strata etc

"Bacteria have been shown to become resistant to anti-biotics over the 
course of (their) generations due to mutations and natural selection. This 
matches the hypothesis of evolution and thus is considered proof of it as a 
theory." Creationists do not argue with natural selection and speciaton (In 
fact rapid speciation is more important to the creation model than it is to 
the evolutionary model) This just shows how ignorant you are of creationist 
literature. For an organism to be able to evolve from single celled 
organism it requires beneficial mutations that increase the information of 
the genome and create a new feature. Bacteria becoming more resistant is 
due to losing control of an enzyme's production. There is no new feature 
added. 

"This matches the hypothesis of evolution and thus is considered proof of 
it as a theory." If we observed a new feature added to an organism that 
would only prove that evolution is possible (if we ignore genetic entropy 
and abiogenesis). To prove it occurred requires finding a series of 
transitional fossils showing the development of a new feature. 

"There is no similar proof for the hypothesis of creationism." Creationists 
accept that we cannot use science to prove the past as it is beyond what 
can be observed, it also requires assumptions of the past and the 
interpretation of evidence can become philosophical. However we like to 
create dilemmas for evolutionists who believe science can do so. ICR has 
found an excessive amounts of C14 in diamonds, dating them under one 
million years (that's as low as it could record). The problem is diamonds 
are said to have formed one billion to three billion years ago. If this was 
the case there should be no C14 left. You cannot say it has been 
contaminated either like you do with dinosaurs fossils (they are frequently 
dated under 50,000 years) because diamonds are the densest naturally 
occurring mineral on earth making it the least likely to get contaminated. 
There is a saying that a diamond is a creationists best friend. Also 
civilizations around the world have legends that are very similar to Adam 
and Eve, the great flood and the tower of babel. This may be considered 
proof that these events occurred.

+erraticbrain I don't think the problem is one of specificity.  There are 
plenty of scientists and philosophers that could give, at least, a 
functional definition of consciousness.  The hard problems are of selecting 
between these competing definitions.  David Chalmers, for example, might 
define consciousness in a way that others thinkers would reject.  However, 
all thinkers with a developed theory of consciousness ought to be able to

comments.text:
+mrTeeMorg Thanks for the reply and for reading my lengthy comment! I think 
a lot of the questions you're asking in this reply, I've had in the past. I 
don't know if I have arrived at the "answer", but I think I've gotten as 
close as I can without having my own neuroscience lab haha. Here's what I 
think:

The reason "you" can watch your ego is for the same reason that my eye can 
watch my arm. One part of the system can look at itself and yet see it as 
separate from itself, but only if it has the ability to *detect objects*. 
There is no "third party watcher" at all, but I can definitely see what you 
mean by using these words. I think it's one system with literally billions 
of components that has resolved a way to detect objects, and think of them 
as separate from everything else. 

Object detection is what allows for language to develop. If you can look at 
a table in a room and think of it as a self-contained, free-standing object 
that is separate from the ground it's on, and separate from the background 
behind it (because those things too are different mental objects), then you 
can say that the object "exists" and you can come up with a *symbol* for 
it. That symbol in our language is "table". So things in the world are more 
accurately "units of thought", rather than units of matter -- which is much 
more porous and/or plasmic in reality when you take the information created 
by our sense instruments out of the picture. 

The first time you ever looked at a table and realized that it was a table 
(probably as a baby seeing an adult point at it and saying "table!"), your 
brain released magnesium, pulling certain clusters of neurons closer 
together (those which were involved with identifying the table), and then 
it used calcium in your body to harden that area of the network to keep the 
new neural correlate in place, so that in the future, those neurons will 
fire faster when a table is detected. These features of the brain are 
called areas of "synaptic plasticity", and it's what physically happens 
when you create a new symbol in your mind. 

There is something like 100 billion neurons in each brain. I think the 
relationships between certain neurons in a given cluster of neurons can 
represent a symbol, because I think that we detect objects by way of 
detecting features, and we feature detect by way of electro-chemical 
computation. Chemicals are altered by electric signals incoming from sense 
organs which inform us of the features of a specific experience. The 
features quickly compound and when they become "noisy" enough (when so many 
signals are going to and from different cortices -- by way of energetic 
stimulation -- all at once causing vivid hallucinations to reverberate) is 
when the prefrontal cortex mediates those inputs and uses logic to deduce 
what something is. The lower cortices create vibrant reproductions of 
reality, and then the PFC reduces them down to symbols. 

The stage where the hallucinations are louder than the signals coming from 
the PFC is called "imagination" or "ideation" because the PFC is allowing 
the brain to "respond freely" to stimuli, and is not mediating as hard as 
it would during a math test for example when symbolic features must be 
specifically resolved or the object will "be false" (math is so stupid). 
When you're dreaming, the PFC is not mediating hardly at all, which is why 
you can have a dream of someone licking your face and you wake up to find 
it's your dog, or have a dream of hearing a weird repetitive flute being 
played in your ear, only to wake to find that the noise was your alarm 
clock and you're late for work. The idea that an annoying noise can sound 
beautiful when sleeping is really interesting to me. 

We are very lazy and slow with object detection when we sleep, and we are 
also not very good at "knowing who/where/what we are" when we are asleep, 
at least not to a certain degree of accuracy. There might be a functional 
correlation between object detection and "self" detection in the brain, and 
"self" probably emerges in the pre-frontal cortex where all other objects 
emerge, if this is indeed the case (I personally think it is). 

You can tell when the prefrontal cortex intervenes when awake too, in 
situations like when you're having some random experience, and then a 
moment later you "realize" you're having the experience. That's 
consciousness showing up to the party, but really it just means those 
clusters of neurons started paying closer attention and sharing information 
about some sudden increase in stimuli. Awareness of reality can suddenly 
become heightened, if the animal is in danger especially. 

I believe that the "self" is just another object in your model of the 
world, albeit the "main object" who associates in an intelligent, dualistic 
way with the animal that produces it for protection of the animal (some 
people mistakenly attribute the ego to "god" and believe they are 
communicating with something external; others like me are happy mistakenly 
believing we are communicating with something internal).

Our brains use the function of object detection to detect other people in 
the environment. If you can have a symbolic representation of another 
person in your brain, then you can certainly have a symbolic representation 
of YOUR person, in your brain. We probably started seeing other people 
first, and then wondered, "am I one of those too?", and the construction of 
ego began. 

*An analogy for how I believe the illusion of identity actually happens:*
Imagine you were trapped in an empty room for eternity with a person who 
was identical to you in every way. Not just looked identical to you, but he 
also did all the same movements as you did when you did them. When you put 
your arm up, he put his up, when you said something, he said that thing -- 
all at the exact same time like an exact replica of you that's doing all 
the things you're doing (creepy right?). Except when you're not doing 
anything, he's allowed to move and talk again at his own free will. 
However, every time he moves or says something, your body then does it too 
-- the two of you are bound to each others' actions. So you are both 
allowed to freely say and do whatever you want, as long as the other person 
isn't saying or doing something; because whatever one person does, the 
other person does simultaneously. Well, eventually, the two of you would 
try to coordinate your actions and movements such that you each take turns 
giving each other enough "autonomous free time", and even when it's not one 
person's free time, you would probably coordinate yourselves in a way that 
you could live in a more unified way with each other. In other words, you 
both would allow a more useful, collective identity to emerge. In effect, 
you would both become the *same person*, but you'd be in two different 
animals. 

If there were 100 billion people in the same [but larger] room, in the same 
situation. Those 100 billion people would all eventually merge into one 
collective identity too. But when you get to that high of a number of 
participants, you would then need a smaller panel of people who represent 
the collective -- a representative identity. An ego. Any time the actions 
in the room got out of sync or one group tried to override another 
(somehow), then the collective would quickly elect a new panel of 
representatives to control the room and represent the motives of the 
collective. This is like the infinite "third party" you were talking about. 
I think the ego has this authoritative ability, as a way to quiet the 
madness that can go on between different areas of the brain. There's an old 
zen saying that says that inside every mind, there lives a master and his 
students. 

There are billions of neurons at any given moment which are engaged in 
modeling your current state of the world. I think that each neuron belongs 
to a different cluster which virtualizes different objects and processes 
different logic, but also, each neuron in the consciousness centers of the 
PFC are constantly sharing with each other the *exact* same information 
about the world, creating an illusion that they all have the same 
information, and thus sharing the illusion that they are all the same thing 
-- that "you" are "one" personality. 

So the ego has the ability to associate with any number of perspectives at 
any time -- the watcher can watch the watcher can watch the watcher 
infinitely -- but only because the ego has the ability to associate with 
any perspective at any time, based on the system of coordination that it 
invented during its brain's infancy. Some people have invented poorer 
systems of intellectual coordination amongst their consciousness centers 
and we call those people "scatter brained", or "all over the place" etc. 
The way we have constructed our individual egos, and all the unique systems 
we've each come up with is what makes some of our personalities so 
interesting to each other, I think.
comments.author: Benny Schmidt

My question is... what is that third party? For example, I can shut my eyes 
and watch all my ego's thoughts... the nitpicking, the worries, the fears, 
the excitements, the random other thoughts, you name it. Anything that I 
can attach "myself" to as my identity and "who" I am, I can also examine 
from a 3rd person perspective.

I can watch as I judge myself either positively or negatively, I can 
examine myself become upset, in a very unattached way. I can watch how my 
body wants to tense up when it's in pain... almost like watching a movie.

Why can I do this? Wouldn't it be safe to assume that if I were JUST ego, 
then examining my ego separate from itself would be impossible?

I'm talking beyond emotions, beyond sensation, beyond visual or auditory 
stimuli, beyond any "feature" we as humans identify ourselves as having.

Why can I (and likely many other people) "watch" my ego? What/Who is that 
watching?

I don't know how else to word my question, it's a hard one to ask, because 
it's so precise, yet so difficult to define.

If I were simply only ego (the physically observable pieces of the human 
nervous system and neurological makeup down to the very chemicals that run 
my emotions and everything else that run on signals), would it still be 
possible for for me to examine myself? Or would I just BE myself, without 
question?

Thanks for the time you put into your informative response, it means a lot 
to me that someone would sit down and write that out... :)
comments.author: mrTeeMorg

comments.text:
+mrTeeMorg I believe that who you refer to when you say "I" is the ego -- 
an intellectual feature of a human being's mind that allows it to be aware 
of itself in its environment, and thus create a model of the world around 
itself in which it is the main character, so that it can more successfully 
survive by way of intellectually valuing its existence. 

As far as *how* it happens, I believe that consciousness is the result of 
an electrochemical attempt by the organism ("you") at timing, integrating, 
and thus unifying multiple streams of sensory data from various channels at 
once in the brain to create a cohesive model of the world. 

Each passing moment, the brain shares information (sights, sounds, smells, 
etc. but also much lower-level information that we do not experience 
consciously) with other parts of the brain and body by way of 
hallucinations (e.g. constant auditory and visual hallucinations happen in 
the mind, but also other hallucinations which attempt to model other 
sensory inputs which reverberate around and create the conscious 
experience) in order to resolve the current state of the ego -- where you 
currently are, what you're doing, where others are in relation to you, etc.

There's a biological need to maintain static routines and permanence as 
much as possible in an ever-changing organism that ages and lives in a 
dynamic environment. So there's also a biological need for a mechanism to 
maintain a permanent state of "identity" about the organism, so that it can 
both understand what and where (and thus "who") it is in relation to other 
people, events, and objects; as well as highly value its own identity so 
that it will do whatever it can to overcome obstacles in its environment. 
Nobody [healthy] wants to die. 

I think that ego is a survival mechanism of an organism that uses 
hallucinations recorded by original sensory experiences to communicate with 
itself about itself and its environment -- that is why "you" are you. So 
you are a result of consciousness, and consciousness is the combined 
hallucinatory experience being produced by and shared within the brain as a 
result of ego functionality. 

We experience consciousness without ego when we dream, when the prefrontal 
cortex is far less active than normal, but some of the other cortices (e.g. 
the visual cortex) are just as active as normal, and so the "visual" 
experience can begin to actually override the "me" experience. Sometimes 
the "me" experience is completely gone and it feels as though raw 
experience can happen in the dream world without my identity being attached 
to it (e.g. it's possible to have a dream in which I am not me). 

In fact, I am only truly me -- or, to be more accurate -- I am only *wholly* 
me when I am awake, because that's when my prefrontal cortex is very active 
in controlling the communications (hallucinations) among my other brain 
organs by muting some channels, illuminating others, and directing the flow 
of my conscious attention onto one subject matter rather than another -- 
sending signals to my eyes to focus, or to my hands to reach for things, 
when necessary, etc. -- in order to serve the goals of my projected (and 
illusory) identity.
comments.author: Benny Schmidt

comments.text:
+John Mills Yes! Exactly... Like that... I was thinking about this some 
more after having forgotten about this post and I came to the following 
conclusion:

Everything is One. Even down to a fundamental level in physics... 
everything is the same 'stuff' (energy). We don't know EVERYTHING there is 
to know about energy. Though, I think we'd like to believe that we do. We 
only know how energy behaves relative to the human experience. That is all. 
Now... I don't have evidence, so what I'm about to say is a theory...

That the universe is a facet or... "feature" (much like the liver is a 
feature of the human body) of a much more complex conscious, infinite 
entity. And that we are that entity (since all things are one), 
experiencing all the possible variations of experience, ever.. which, in my 
opinion, are also infinite, thus an infinite universe. That doesn't mean 
"we" (flesh and blood) are the entity (not in its entirety), but rather, 
this flesh and blood is simply a 'housing' made by the entity, for the 
entity. Okay so with that said, now to the sperm and eggs...

My conclusion was: No matter which sperm or egg came together, it would 
still be "You" experiencing life. Because the body is a facilitator for the 
conscious experience in this 4-dimensional form of existence. 

"You" are not your body. Rather, "You" are the essence of what your body 
"carries." If you lose your arm, did you lose a piece of yourself? If you 
replace every part of your body with other cells, do you become someone 
else? No.

You are not your eyes, but you are what sees. You're not your ears, but you 
are what hears. You're not your mouth, but you are what speaks... see what 
I'm saying? You're not your nervous system, but you are what feels.

So, why sperm and egg, if the only goal is to "house" a "slice" of this 
infinite consciousness? Well, that's where I go into this infinite 
consciousness wanting to experience variation, in all its infinite forms... 
this infinite consciousness/entity has mechanisms to provide the best 
possible environment for automatic growth and progress (in this specific 
instance of reality - 4 dimensions, physical, ever-changing)... To have 
this, there needs to be duality, competition, difficulty, trial. Without 
these things, there is no growth and potentially, no change. And therefore, 
no new experiences.

There exists Good and Evil, high and low, hot and cold, slow and fast, easy 
and difficult... and apart from any of these, the other would not exist. 
Because they are relative. If something can be beautiful, other things 
become ugly.

Granted, these are human-made concepts and do not exist in objective 
reality. But the ability to measure their seeming existence, at least on an 
agreeable subjective level, does suggest it is real. At least for humans.

We live in a world of duality. This existence, or rather, this current form 
of a finite experience we get to have, is literally made of opposites. 

I have a lot more, but I'm having a hard time articulating and I don't want 
to talk your eyes off. So I'll cut it off here.

Remember, the above is theory. I'm just trying to figure out what the heck 
all this is. lol

comments.text:
The sub conscious, as most colloquially know it, doesn't really exist. The 
closest thing to it would be the automatic processes that Hank mentioned 
when talking about the squirrel. There are thousands (if not more) of 
automatic processes going on in your brain at any one time, and these 
collectively are sometimes thought of as the subconscious. Freud - who was 
wrong about almost everything - described consciousness as being divided 
into two distinct domains, with the person being completely unaware of the 
lower state. While we tend to ignore the automatic processes, you can make 
yourself conscious of them by simply directing your attention to them. Your 
heart is beating right now, air is passing through your trachea, you blink 
very frequently. Automatic processes that you are now conscious of. The 
common conception of subconscious is some mysterious realm that requires 
psychotherapy to unlock, but the truth is it doesn't really exist.

captions.text:
Here’s a riddle, my Hobbitses: What’s
something we all experience, all the time,

that we can’t really measure, and barely
have words to define? You can’t hold it

in your hand, or take a bite out of it. It
isn’t something you learn or practice; it
just IS.

Consciousness.
Every science has certain concepts that are

so fundamental, yet abstract, that we have
a hard time finding the appropriate words

to describe them. Ask a physicist and they’ll
tell you energy and space defy simple definitions.

Biologists know if something is alive, but
have a harder time explaining what life actually

is. Ask a psychologist what consciousness
is, and you’ll get…you’ll get a slippery

answer.
For the purposes of this conversation, we’re

going to actually loosely define consciousness
as our awareness of ourselves and our environment.

It’s this awareness that allows us to take
in and organize information from many sources

and senses, at once.
American psychologist William James thought

of consciousness as a continuously moving,
shifting, and unbroken stream, hence the term

“stream of consciousness.” Others think
of it as the brain’s roving flashlight,

shining down an unbroken beam of light that
highlights one thing, and then moves on to

the next.
The point is, your conscious experience is

forever shifting--for example, right now hopefully
you’re focused on the words coming out of

my mouth, but with a little shift - your mind
might wander to how you really should shower

today, and your chair is uncomfortable, and
you suddenly have to pee, and can you believe
what Bernice said?!
Do I smell pizza?

HEY! EYES HERE! WE’RE LEARNING!
Beyond that moment-to-moment shifting, consciousness

allows us to contemplate life, think about
infinity, and ride a unicycle across a tightrope
while juggling melons, at least in theory.

Our consciousness helps us plan our futures,
consider consequences, and reflect on the

past. It is both the most familiar, and the
most mysterious part of our lives.

It’s kind of like The Force -- but for the
little universes inside our heads.

[INTRO]
Throughout our daily lives we flit back and

forth between various states of consciousness,
including waking, sleeping, and various altered

states. These can occur spontaneously, like
dreaming, or be physiologically sparked, like

a drug-induced hallucination, or be triggered
psychologically, through meditation or hypnosis,
for example.

We’re going to take the next three episodes
to look closely at these different states

of consciousness, but let’s start with what
it really means to be awake.

For centuries, scientists learned what they
could about the brain solely through clinical

observation. And they learned a lot, for sure,
but with today’s technology, we’re actually

able to see some of the structures and activity
inside a living, working brain - its electrical,

metabolic, and magnetic signatures displayed
on screens for our wonder and amusement.

The field of cognitive neuroscience is the
study of how brain activity is linked with

our mental processes, including thinking,
perception, memory, and language. Like other

kinds of neuroscience, it uses neuroimaging
technologies to consider links between specific

brain states and conscious experiences.
And there’s more than one way to scan a

brain. Structural imaging shows the brain’s
anatomy, and is useful in identifying large-scale

tumors, diseases, and injuries. In contrast,
functional imaging shows us electromagnetic

or metabolic activity in the brain, like blood
flow, to let us observe correlations between

specific mental functions and activity in
particular brain areas.

So, yes, neuroimaging has been revolutionizing
the field of psychology, much like telescopes

and microscopes did for astronomy and biology.
But on the other hand, some of this technology

is very new, and there’s plenty of disagreement
about how to interpret neuroimaging findings.

Remember, correlation does not equal causation.
So, activity in a certain brain region while

having certain kinds of thoughts might be
useful to know, but it’s not the end of

the conversation.
We’ve already talked a lot about how function

is often localized in the brain and how everything
psychological is simultaneously biological--so

it stands to reason our thoughts and emotions
could in part be illustrated by a bright flare

on a dark screen.
We’ve also collected a fair amount of evidence

that we don’t just have one layer of consciousness
- a single tape playing various tunes - but

rather, something more like two layers, each
supported by its own personal bio-psycho-social

pit crew.
I’m talking about one of the dual process

models of consciousness--the idea that our
conscious, deliberate mind could be saying,

look! a squirrel! while our implicit, automatic
mind is simultaneously subprocessing like

a computer: color: brown, tail: bushy, movement:
climbing, distance: 20 meters, association:

my sister had a squirrel phobia as a child,
implicit bias: I think that squirrels are

ruining America. All of which might weigh
upon my behavior upon seeing the little guy.

By some estimates, all your senses are scooping
up nearly 11 million bits of information,

EVERY SECOND. And yet, you consciously register
only about 40 at time. So how do we keep focused

and filter out all the chatter to actually
get stuff done?

With selective attention, of course!
Selective attention is how we focus our consciousness

on one particular stimulus or group of stimuli,
effectively tuning out the rest. Your consciousness

is like a spotlight on a busy stage. There
are other things going on around you that

your automatic, subprocessor brain is covertly
registering. But for those moments when you

shine your spotlight, most of the other stimuli
fall away.

Try it at home! Right now, you’re consciously
watching this lesson on consciousness. You

probably don’t notice the feel of your socks
on your feet, or the tongue that’s inside

your mouth, always filling up your mouth with
tongue! But as soon as I mention it, the spotlight

of your attention turns to them, you feel
those socks on your feet, and you’re like

wow! It’s weird that there’s a tongue
in my mouth!

The classic auditory example of selective
attention is the cocktail party effect. You

could be in a room with 47 people jabbering
away, and yet be able to concentrate your

hearing on one conversation, tuning out the
rest of the voices and background music. But,

if the couple next to you were to speak your
name, suddenly your cognitive radar would

light up and your attention would whip around
to the sound of your name, probably trying

to figure out if Bernice was talking behind
your back again.
Bernice!!

This roving spotlight of selective attention
is pretty handy most of the time, for spies

and laypeople alike. But it can also be dangerous,
if you’re being dumb, and say, texting and

driving.
When you shift your primary selective attention

from driving to OMG, LOLOLOLOLOL, you also
unwittingly activate your selective inattention,

which means that you failed to see that cyclist
who you almost ran over, which would not only

have ruined her life but also yours so DON’T
TEXT AND DRIVE!

In fact, when your full attention is directed
elsewhere, you’d be astounded by the scope

of obvious things you fail to notice. It’s
called inattentional blindness.

You may have even already been subject to
one of the most famous experiments of inattentional

blindness...the Invisible Gorilla or, sometimes,
the Moonwalking bear. Just google either of

those things if you want to be tested on your
awareness and then come back.

Pretty great, right?! Given the prompt to
count the number of passes one team makes,

your consciousness is focused on following
the players and the ball, nothing else. You

don’t see the players in black, they’re
the distraction... also you certainly don’t

see the dancing gorilla...or bear...whichever
one.

The original version of this experiment found
that about 50% of people didn’t notice that
there was A GORILLA WALKING THROUGH THE ROOM!

THAT is how powerfully selective our attention
can be. Something to remember next time you’re
behind the wheel.

But you know who understands and exploits
inattentional blindness better than anyone?

Magicians!
Except they call it misdirection. Famous modern

magician Teller, of Penn and Teller, says
“Every time you perform a magic trick you’re

engaging in a experimental psychology.”
And we can’t help but be rubes.

Magicians also prey on our change blindness,
the psychological phenomenon in which we fail

to notice changes in our environment. And
no, I don’t mean climate change. I mean

the failure to recognize the difference between
what was there a moment ago, versus what is

there now.
For example, I have changed shirts several
times since this lesson started.

In a well-known and often-copied experiment,
sometimes called the “person swap,” an

experimenter will stop someone in a park and
ask for directions. And then, during some

staged interruption, the original experimenter
will leave and be replaced with a totally

different person. Half the time, the subject
doesn’t even notice.
Fun!

One of the many perks of studying psychology
with me is you learn all kinds of new ways
to mess with people!

But while change blindness makes for some
really cool parlor tricks, this failure to

notice certain things can be dangerous -- say,
faulty memories lead to false eyewitness testimonies

in court, or when friends get deadlocked in
a he-said, she-said disagreement.

So, my friends, use The Force. But use it
wisely. As one of my favorite psychologists

once advised: “A Jedi uses the Force for
knowledge and defense, never for attack.”

Actually, that was Yoda.
Anyway, the bottom line is, we are far less

aware of what’s going on around us than
we think we are. And that’s just when we’re

awake! Imagine what might slip your notice
when you’re half-asleep, drunk, hypnotized,

or hallucinating! That’s what we’re gonna
talk about next time.

Thanks for watching this episode of Crash
Course, if you were selectively conscious

of my words, you got introduced the our constant
struggle to define consciousness, learned

a little bit about neuroimaging and its developing
role in psychological science, how our consciousness

is split into two pieces, deliberate and automatic,
and how the brain can be selectively attentive,

selectively inattentive, and blind to changes
in some surprisingly major ways.
